sub_title: CS Manager at Solar Monkey | Diversity, Equity & Inclusion | MA linguistics | social impact | change maker | polyglot
summary:
The right of expression is a tremendously important good for me. However, to be heard is even increasingly important with the challenges that we are facing today, as we are trying to create a peaceful, equitable, inclusive and sustainable society.

As a changemaker the above is what I am striving for.

Expression is worth nothing if nobody is curious enough to listen.
In our personal life, at work and school we should have the courage to:
- actually listen to one another and restrain from being focused on our own opinion only
- treat every story equally and not give preference to one story over another (see Ted-Talk by Adichie)
- listen before judging or not judge at all just based on assumptions.
- challenge our own (unconscious) biases and restrain from trusting them and just acting upon them.

Currently I am working at Solar Monkey, a SAAS company that is striving to accelerate the solar energy transition for a more sustainable future. As a Customer Success Manager I support Gold and Silver Clients in successfully reaching their business objectives.

In everything I do, I am aiming to bring systemic change for a more inclusive and sustainable world in a strategic manner.
I try to challenge myself and others to see the world through an DE&I lens and to have the courage to step from the known into the unknown. 

Only if we can tolerate what we do not know and leave our comfort zone, will we be able to bring about change. - Sarah A. Niggemann

- After having studied the French lexifier creoles extensively for my final French examination (Staatsexamen), a fellow student and I were so passionate about these languages and culture that we wanted to experience them in real-life. We flew down to Seychelles and had the chance to apply our knowledge. 
"One of the greatest moments of the experience was for me when we were talking to a local in Seselwa creole, while at the same time meeting tourists from Montpellier who were fluent in the minority language Occitan. Having these two minority languages, which I had extensively studied before, around one table while simultaneously experiencing ecotourism was amazing!"', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Sarah A.', 'last_name': 'Niggemann ♾️', 'name': None, 'headline': 'CS Manager at Solar Monkey | Diversity, Equity & Inclusion | MA linguistics | social impact | change maker | polyglot'}]}, {'title': 'Field Research Curaçao', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'description': '- Research for my Master thesis on the island: The French influence on the Sephardic variety of Papiamentu
